Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Summer Research Internships in Manufacturing and Techno-Entrepreneurship Preparation

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
BROADER SIGNIFICANCE OF THE PROJECT:

This new three year Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site focuses on manufacturing related research and provides student interns with techno-entrepreneurship experiences. The potential impact of this REU site arises from the students' involvement in one of the most exciting and rapidly developing areas of engineering - manufacturing research, both basic and applied. This unique experience will play a transformational role in preparing future leaders in the emerging areas of manufacturing. The research topics also address some of the cutting-edge manufacturing technologies which will be key areas for the US industry and national competitiveness for the next few decades. Furthermore, the process and the focus of recruitment on participation of underrepresented groups will lead to a much broader exposure of young students in this group. This exposure and experience will lead to the development and improvement of disadvantaged communities through the empowering potential of techno-entrepreneurship. It is anticipated that this site will also impact the nation's need to increase the number of U.S. citizens and permanent residents engaged in research-related and start-up careers in private sector.

PROJECT DESCRIPTION:

The five project objectives of the REU site are to: 1) provide undergraduate students with opportunities to conduct manufacturing research; 2) increase the number of future professionals in manufacturing; 3) allow interns to self-assess their interest in techno-entrepreneurship; 4) allow interns to self-assess their interest in graduate school, and; 5) enable the College of Engineering at Tennessee Tech University (TTU) to become, and be perceived as, a nationally recognized top tier undergraduate and graduate program. Each year, a different group of ten talented freshmen though senior undergraduate students will be nationally recruited to conduct research on the TTU campus as part of this ten-week summer internship program. Ten faculty members and ten graduate students from the College of Engineering will serve as mentors. The program includes a Lean LauchPad short course, professional development workshops, and an off-campus techno-entrepreneurship enrichment program. Recruitment of summer interns will be from five groups: 1) institutions with a limited STEM research base (at least 50% of the students); 2) minority institutions; 3) women; 4) persons with disabilities, and; 5) TTU programs (no more than 30% of total from TTU). Selection of interns will be based upon their career objectives, academic qualifications, past work experiences, underrepresented groups and institution type.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall goal of the three-year REU Site project was to provide student interns with innovation and technically focused entrepreneurship (Techno-entrepreneurship) experiences.  The NSF I-Corps program inspired this approach. Additionally, the program addressed a key area of national interest, namely, manufacturing research. This research experience nurtured the students’ interest in research in general, and encouraged them to explore graduate studies opportunities, with the ultimate goal to increase the number of future professionals in manufacturing.

Thirty students took part in this experience over the three-year period: ten in 2015-16, nine in 2016-17, and 11 in 2017-18. The intern recruitment focused on students nationwide from institutions with limited research facilities.  Particular efforts were made to recruit those from underrepresented groups in engineering and manufacturing, specifically racial minorities and women. Students from Tennessee Technological University (TTU) programs were also included. Selection criteria were based upon career objectives, academic qualifications, past work experiences, membership in an underrepresented group, and institution type.

All 30 interns who participated in the summer REU experience overt the 3-year period were assigned a faculty advisor who helped them identify and develop a research topic in an area relevant to manufacturing research. Projects were initially conducted with individual students and later in groups of two to three students. Each student was also assigned a graduate student mentor who worked with them directly in the faculty advisor’s lab.

 

In all three years (2015-16, 2016-17, and 2017-18), student interns evaluated the project throughout by assessing the REU activities, seminars and workshops, and presentations by other interns through using various means. The following are highlights of the evaluation findings.

  • An overwhelming majority of participants responded that they actively participated in their research projects: 80% in 2015, 100% in 2016, and 91% in 2017.
  • All participants reported that Faculty Advisor Meetings were beneficial to some degree. The meetings were reported as “Very Beneficial” by 50% in 2015, 33% in 2016, and 82% in 2017.
  • Graduate student mentorship was consistently valuable to participants; reports of “Somewhat Valuable” and “Very Valuable” were 90% in 2015, 89% in 2016, and 91% in 2017.
  • The percentages of those who are at least likely to continue their research in their assigned areas were 40%, 44.4%, and 45.5% in 2014, 2016, and 2017, respectively.
  • The REU experience reinforced more than it undermined the interns’ willingness to continue in the field of engineering. The percentages of participants who reported “Reinforced” or “Strongly Reinforced” were 90% in 2015, 78% in 2016, and 73% in 2017.   
  • The interns’ reported that the REU experience influenced their decision to consider graduate school more than it discouraged them. Respondent rates of” Encouraged” and “Strongly Encouraged” were 80% in 2015, 78% in 2016, and 46% in 2017.

 

In summary, the best aspects of the program as reported by the interns include the following:

  • Hands-on research experience, from design through testing,
  • Access to equipment and proper training for equipment use,
  • Tours to manufacturing companies,
  • Teamwork, friendships, and networking connections,
  • Graduate school information,
  • Building leadership and communication skills, and
  • Learning to use 3D printers.

 The project resulted in at least five journal publications and nine conference presentations by both faculty, the interns, and graduate mentors.
